Create a new GridStore instance
Modes

"r" - read only. This is the default mode.
"w" - write in truncate mode. Existing data will be overwriten.

methods.name: openDownloadStreamByName

parameters.name: filename
parameters.desc: The name of the file to stream

options.name: revision
options.desc: The revision number relative to the oldest file with the given filename. 0 gets you the oldest file, 1 gets you the 2nd oldest, -1 gets you the newest.

options.name: start
options.desc: Optional 0-based offset in bytes to start streaming from

options.name: end
options.desc: Optional 0-based offset in bytes to stop streaming before

methods.desc: Returns a readable stream (GridFSBucketReadStream) for streaming thefile with the given name from GridFS. If there are multiple files withthe same name, this will stream the most recent file with the given name(as determined by the uploadDate field). You can set the revisionoption to change this behavior.

methods.name: abort

parameters.name: callback
parameters.desc: called when chunks are successfully removed or error occurred

methods.desc: Places this write stream into an aborted state (all future writes fail)and deletes all chunks that have already been written.

methods.name: end

parameters.name: callback
parameters.desc: Function to call when all files and chunks have been persisted to MongoDB

methods.desc: Tells the stream that no more data will be coming in. The stream willpersist the remaining data to MongoDB, write the files document, andthen emit a 'finish' event.

methods.name: abort

parameters.name: callback
parameters.desc:
optional
called when the cursor is successfully closed or an error occurred.

methods.desc: Marks this stream as aborted (will never push another data event)and kills the underlying cursor. Will emit the 'end' event, and thenthe 'close' event once the cursor is successfully killed.

methods.name: end

parameters.name: end
parameters.desc: Offset in bytes to stop reading at

methods.desc: Sets the 0-based offset in bytes to start streaming from. Throwsan error if this stream has entered flowing mode(e.g. if you've already called on('data'))

methods.name: start

parameters.name: start
parameters.desc: Offset in bytes to start reading at

methods.desc: Sets the 0-based offset in bytes to start streaming from. Throwsan error if this stream has entered flowing mode(e.g. if you've already called on('data'))

methods.name: Long

parameters.name: low
parameters.desc: the low (signed) 32 bits of the Long.

parameters.name: high
parameters.desc: the high (signed) 32 bits of the Long.

methods.desc:
Defines a Long class for representing a 64-bit two's-complementinteger value, which faithfully simulates the behavior of a Java "Long". Thisimplementation is derived from LongLib in GWT.
Constructs a 64-bit two's-complement integer, given its low and high 32-bitvalues as signed integers.  See the from* functions below for moreconvenient ways of constructing Longs.
The internal representation of a Long is the two given signed, 32-bit values.We use 32-bit pieces because these are the size of integers on whichJavascript performs bit-operations.  For operations like addition andmultiplication, we split each number into 16-bit pieces, which can easily bemultiplied within Javascript's floating-point representation without overflowor change in sign.
In the algorithms below, we frequently reduce the negative case to thepositive case by negating the input(s) and then post-processing the result.Note that we must ALWAYS check specially whether those values are MIN_VALUE(-2^63) because -MIN_VALUE == MIN_VALUE (since 2^63 cannot be represented asa positive number, it overflows back into a negative).  Not handling thiscase would often result in infinite recursion.

parameters.name: type
parameters.desc: The type of filter (currently only class)

methods.desc: Set what classes to log.

methods.desc: Returns a Long representing the 64-bit integer that comes by concatenating the given high and low bits. Each is assumed to use 32 bits.

parameters.desc: the high (signed) 32 bits of the Timestamp.

methods.desc:
This type is for INTERNAL use in MongoDB only and should not be used in applications.The appropriate corresponding type is the JavaScript Date type.
Defines a Timestamp class for representing a 64-bit two's-complementinteger value, which faithfully simulates the behavior of a Java "Timestamp". Thisimplementation is derived from TimestampLib in GWT.
Constructs a 64-bit two's-complement integer, given its low and high 32-bitvalues as signed integers.  See the from* functions below for moreconvenient ways of constructing Timestamps.
The internal representation of a Timestamp is the two given signed, 32-bit values.We use 32-bit pieces because these are the size of integers on whichJavascript performs bit-operations.  For operations like addition andmultiplication, we split each number into 16-bit pieces, which can easily bemultiplied within Javascript's floating-point representation without overflowor change in sign.
In the algorithms below, we frequently reduce the negative case to thepositive case by negating the input(s) and then post-processing the result.Note that we must ALWAYS check specially whether those values are MIN_VALUE(-2^63) because -MIN_VALUE == MIN_VALUE (since 2^63 cannot be represented asa positive number, it overflows back into a negative).  Not handling thiscase would often result in infinite recursion.

methods.name: Timestamp.fromBits
methods.desc: Returns a Timestamp representing the 64-bit integer that comes by concatenating the given high and low bits. Each is assumed to use 32 bits.

methods.name: Timestamp.fromInt
methods.desc: Returns a Timestamp representing the given (32-bit) integer value.

methods.name: Timestamp.fromNumber
methods.desc: Returns a Timestamp representing the given value, provided that it is a finite number. Otherwise, zero is returned.

parameters.desc: the textual representation of the Timestamp.

methods.desc: Returns a Timestamp representation of the given string, written using the given radix.
